Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Designing Tailorable Bioplastics for Biomedical Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs) are biodegradable and biocompatible plastics that are natively produced by bacteria as an energy storage material. These plastics have physical properties similar to petroleum based plastics, with existing applications ranging from bulk commodity goods to tissue engineering materials. The biodegradable aspect of PHAs leads toward environmentally sustainable applications, such as biodegradable shopping bags, whereas the biocompatibility of PHAs allows for the pursuit of medical applications such as wound dressings and tissue scaffolds. In collaboration with Dr. Keiji Numata, a leading expert in biopolymers at the RIKEN institute in Japan, this study aims to develop cutting edge PHA plastics with enhanced physical properties. This research will result in a novel PHA with a high degree of cross-linking, which is hypothesized to increase flexibility in stiff and brittle PHAs, and incorporate shape-memory features into soft and elastic PHAs. Stronger and flexible PHAs may find uses as bone scaffolds to promote rapid healing, or as stents for patients suffering from collapsed arteries. Softer PHAs could be used as artificial tissue, such as heart valves or nerve grafts for repairing damaged neurons.

To achieve this goal, unsaturated PHAs will be chemically modified by thiolene click chemistry. Using a polythiol linker, the PHA side-chain alkene functional groups will be cross-linked using UV light. It is anticipated that controlling the extent of the modification will result in plastics with tailorable physical properties, tunable as required for specific applications. In addition to physical properties, PHAs will be tested for biocompatibility to ensure they maintain relevant for medical uses. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this work a type biodegradable plastic, called polyhydroxyalkanoate, was used to fabricate scaffolds for applications in tissue engineering.  These plastics were produced from an engineered strain of bacteria that is able to convert sustainable carbon sources, such as sugars and oils, into a biodegradable polymer. The plastics produced are inherently biocompatible, which makes them relevant for applcations in the field of tissue engineering.  In this study, the plastic produced was used to fabricate porous scaffolds for applications in biomedical applications, such as skin grafts, vasculation, and connective tissue replacement.  The porous scaffolds were significantly improved through chemical modification, where thiol-ene click chemistry was employed to cross-link the polymeric scaffold. This cross-linking resulted in improvements to tensile strength that will afford greater diversity in the applicable target tissues for biomedical devices. Importantly, it was found that the chemical cross-linking did not negatively impact cell growth, as determined by culturing the scaffolds with human mesenchymal stem cells. This work provides evidence that rational design of new plastics through chemical modification can be used to expand the use of these polyhydroxyalkanoate polymers beyond currently available applications, and that biomedical scaffolds made from this polymer will serve as an attractive material for soft tissue replacement.

Modified by: Alex C Levine
